lines.content: JRobo is a command line application that you can use as your personal task tracker assistant.
JRobo consists of various different commands and three type of tasks, which are **todo**, **deadline**, and **event**.
**Todos** are tasks that do not have any specific time or duration.
**Deadlines** are tasks that have a specific deadline that can be specified while adding.
**Events** are tasks that have a specific time and duration that can be specified while adding.
Note that, even if the application is terminated, JRobo will keep all tasks for you in his memory.
Tasks can be added using **todo**, **deadline**, **event** commands, or with their shortcut notations.
Tasks can be removed using **delete** command, or with its shortcut **del**.
All tasks can be listed using **list** command, or with its shortcut **ls**.
Tasks can be marked as done using **mark** command, or with its shortcut **m**.
Tasks can be marked as done using **unmark** command, or with its shortcut **um**.
All tasks can be searched and filtered using **find** command, or with its shortcut **f**.
Application can be quited using **quit** command, or with its shortcut **q**.
[E][ ] Ege Demirkirkan attend CS2113 lecture (at: Friday 18 Feb 2022 from 4 to 6pm)
JRobo is a command line application that you can use as your personal task tracker assistant.
JRobo consists of various different commands and three type of tasks, which are **todo**, **deadline**, and **event**.
**Todos** are tasks that do not have any specific time or duration.
**Deadlines** are tasks that have a specific deadline that can be specified while adding.
**Events** are tasks that have a specific time and duration that can be specified while adding.
Note that, even if the application is terminated, JRobo will keep all tasks for you in his memory.
Tasks can be added using **todo**, **deadline**, **event** commands, or with their shortcut notations.
Tasks can be removed using **delete** command, or with its shortcut **del**.
All tasks can be listed using **list** command, or with its shortcut **ls**.
Tasks can be marked as done using **mark** command, or with its shortcut **m**.
Tasks can be marked as done using **unmark** command, or with its shortcut **um**.
All tasks can be searched and filtered using **find** command, or with its shortcut **f**.
Application can be quited using **quit** command, or with its shortcut **q**.

* Returns the keyword of the user's command as a String object.
* Returns the description of the user's CLI task command
* Returns the time details of the user's CLI task command
* @return the task commands' details regarding time

* Returns a boolean value that determines whether the CLI command is valid and properly formatted.
* @return a true or false according to correctness of command's format
* Returns the type of the task given in the command
* @throws InvalidFormatException if the format of the command is wrong,
* Returns the necessary information to be able to recreate Task objects.
* @param taskStr String object extracted from the text file that is used as a storage
* @return three element array, in which, command's description, time detail, and type respectively.
* Storage is the class that provides save and load functionalities on each run of the program.
* This method saves tasks to the storage
* This method loads tasks from the storage
* Task is the parent class of Deadline, Event, Todo.
* @return "X" or " " according to the done status of the task
* Returns the main text of the task.
* Returns a String object representing the Task
* @return the String that represents the task in the following format; [{status_icon}]{description}
* TaskManager is the class that manages everything regarding Task, Deadline, Event, Todo classes
printWithSeparator("Hello from JRobo! I'm your personal assistant!",
"Nice to meet you. What can I do for you?");
* This method displays all the tasks kept in the storage.
printWithSeparator("You have no tasks to list.");
System.out.println("\tHere are the tasks in your list:");
* This method is used for handle 'mark' command. It changes the status icon of the task.
* @param input String object representing the command in the following format; 'mark {int}'
printWithSeparator("Nice! I've marked this task as done:", "\t[" + task.getStatusIcon() + "] "
printWithSeparator("Please enter a valid task number to mark");
* This method is used for handle 'unmark' command. It changes the status icon of the task.
* @param input String object representing the command in the following format; 'unmark {int}'
printWithSeparator("Nice! I've marked this task as undone:", "\t[" + task.getStatusIcon() + "] "
printWithSeparator("Please enter a valid task number to unmark");
* This method add a task to the storage of the program.
* @param description main text of the task
* @param detail      time detail of the task, null if the command is not the type deadline or event.
* @param loadFlag    boolean value that represents whether the task should be loaded
* @throws InvalidTypeException if the type of the command is wrong,
public void addTask(String description, String detail, String type, boolean loadFlag)
printWithSeparator("Got it. I've added this task:", "\t" + task,
"Now, you have " + tasks.size() + " in the list.");
* This method delete a task from the storage of the program.
* @param index specifies the task to remove
printWithSeparator("Noted. I've removed this task:", "\t" + tasks.get(index - 1).toString(),
"Now you have " + (tasks.size() - 1) + " tasks in the list.");
printWithSeparator("Bye. Hope to see you again soon!");
* This method search through the storage to find the related task to the search key
System.out.println("\tHere are the matching tasks in your list:");
* UI is the class that provides the program with the CLI view.
* This method creates and maintain the CLI view of the program.
